channel.title: How to get better ambient occlusion in Blender (2.5)
channel.description:
Ok, so this is pretty much going to be my first 'tutorial' i guess. without further or do..
some of you who use blender may have a constant problem with lighting. you either have to much lights and light, or not enough. in order to get around having to place a lot of lights, there's ambient occlusion. now ambient occlusion is a tool that produces ambient light around the scene and determines shadows based on proximity to other objects. now in the 'World tab, there's a tab with a little check box and 'Ambient occlusion' check that box. now if you render it out, it'll look something like this, (except what your scene is. just look at shadows) [IMG]http://i53.tinypic.com/a40ah.jpg[/img]
you'll notice that theres A TON of noise in the render. in order to fix this, go to the 'gather' tab (like right under ambient occlusion and EV) look for the thing that says 'samples'. mine was defaulted at 5, yours may be different, but yeah just crank that number up. between 10-100 should do.
the noise in the image is now reduced. :o [IMG]http://i54.tinypic.com/bi0460.jpg[/img] (Done on 16 samples.)
well thats it. i know i didnt go in much detail, but this should suffice. if you want to learn more, i would recommend you experiment.
(this model is a project im working on. i'm going to fully model a character, and possible rig and animate him and probably make a little amination. the body piece used in the so called 'tutorial' was just a practice model so i got a feel for armor modeling.)

item.title: How to get better ambient occlusion in Blender (2.5)
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

[quote=“Timberpig., post:5, topic:374097”]well i figure most of you are like me.
I NEVER go to the help section. EVER… haha and i figure no one else would either :P[/quote]
Haha. I go there. I probably have the record for most topics in there. And most questions unanswered…

Read full topic

item.title: How to get better ambient occlusion in Blender (2.5)
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“Timberpig., post:3, topic:374097”]i had no idea of such a thing :o
it’s probably just a NVidia thing.
i mean (with enough time) i can render out AO on my 1998 computer xD
(yeah, thats why i dont use it :o)[/quote]
Hmm, well just incase someone thinks they might need to enable it, here is a small pic showing you where.

item.title: How to get better ambient occlusion in Blender (2.5)
item.dc:creator: @Timberpig1 Timberpig.
item.description:
@Timberpig1 wrote:

Ok, so this is pretty much going to be my first ‘tutorial’ i guess.
without further or do…

some of you who use blender may have a constant problem with lighting.
you either have to much lights and light, or not enough.
in order to get around having to place a lot of lights, there’s ambient occlusion.
now ambient occlusion is a tool that produces ambient light around the scene and determines shadows based
on proximity to other objects.
now in the 'World tab, there’s a tab with a little check box and ‘Ambient occlusion’
check that box. now if you render it out, it’ll look something like this, (except what your scene is. just look at shadows)

you’ll notice that theres A TON of noise in the render.
in order to fix this, go to the ‘gather’ tab (like right under ambient occlusion and EV)
look for the thing that says ‘samples’. mine was defaulted at 5, yours may be different, but yeah
just crank that number up. between 10-100 should do.

the noise in the image is now reduced. :o

(Done on 16 samples.)

well thats it. i know i didnt go in much detail, but this should suffice.
if you want to learn more, i would recommend you experiment.

(this model is a project im working on. i’m going to fully model a character, and possible rig and animate him and probably make a little amination.
the body piece used in the so called ‘tutorial’ was just a practice model so i got a feel for armor modeling.)
